awd_titl_txt: Kinetics, Mechanism, and Active Site Requirements for Hydrodeoxygenation over Reducible Metal Oxides
awd_abstract_narration:
Bio-oils are obtained from the fast pyrolysis of biomass, and their conversion into fuels and chemicals represents a sustainable alternative to coal, natural gas, and petroleum sources.  The critical step in upgrading bio-oil is the selective removal of oxygen atoms from the lignin-derived fraction under ambient pressures of hydrogen and in the presence of a catalyst (otherwise known as "hydrodeoxygenation").  The ideal catalyst for hydrodeoxygenation would be abundant, inexpensive and easy to handle, while also being active, selective, hydrogen efficient, stable, and regenerable. The goal of this research project is to develop a molecular-level understanding of the chemical and physical processes occurring during the hydrodeoxygenation of biomass-derived model compounds over a class of catalysts called reducible metal oxides.  Primarily, the studies will focus on cerium oxide (ceria), a material widely used commercially as an oxygen storage component in automotive exhaust systems.  The research project serves as a training ground for graduate and undergraduate students to perform cutting edge research.  The researchers also will participate in outreach activities in the Houston area, including Energy Day and Chevron Girls Engineering the Future Day, and they will host high school students in the laboratory and provide them with hands-on research experience as part of Project ACS SEED.

The fact that bulk ceria selectively cleaves carbon-oxygen bonds in biomass-derived model compounds raises interesting fundamental questions regarding the nature and density of oxygen vacancies in reducible metal oxides.  The precise mechanism through which carbon-oxygen bond cleavage over ceria occurs will be studied via four experimental steps: (1) demonstration of the potential of bulk ceria as a hydrodeoxygenation catalyst; (2) elucidation of the mechanism of anisole hydrodeoxygenation over bulk ceria; (3) establishing the active site requirements for hydrodeoxygenation over cerium oxide; and (4) understanding the effect of doping on active site identity, density, and efficacy.  This research project aims to optimize energy, cost, and atom-efficiency of biomass conversion processes by guiding the design of hydrodeoxygenation catalysts and clarifying the identity of the mechanistic steps involved in Mars-van Krevelen/reverse Mars-van Krevelen redox cycles, ubiquitous in the realm of bulk oxide catalysis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project was focused on investigating active sites and reaction mechanisms involved in the conversion of renewable biomass feedstock to fuels and chemicals. Specifically, hydrodeoxygenation and hydrogenation reactions ubiquitous in biomass conversion applications were investigated, and catalyst design parameters that maximize reaction rates and selectivity were identified. Methods for quantifying the density of reduced metal ions such as Ce3+ in-situ under reaction conditions were developed and applied toward elucidating the relationship between active site local coordination environment and catalytic function.

Transient kinetic tools were developed for counting active sites under reaction conditions. CO was shown to result in supramonolayer coverages at sub-ambient titrant pressures, and a detailed analysis of transient data was used to extrapolate to obtain accurate site counts. A theoretical and experimental analysis of 2F5/2 - 2F7/2 electronic transitions was advanced to enable the quantitative estimation of oxygen vacancy concentrations - a development that was critical to enumerating site requirements for hydrogen exchange and dehydration reactions.

Another critical scientific challenge that was addressed as part of this project was a resolution to the conundrum of maximum hydrogenation rates being achieved at intermediate, not high degrees of surface ceria reduction. We showed, using a combination of steady state and transient kinetic tools (including  isotopic ones) that the entirety of the rate data can be explained merely by accounting for changes in active site ensemble distributions rather than changes in the identity or kinetic relevance of elementary steps mediating hydrogenative turnovers.

Multiple graduate and undergraduate students were trained as part of this project. NSF funds facilitated their extensive training in catalyst synthesis, materials characterization, and kinetic analysis. The technical skills that these students acquired during their graduate studies, combined with their experiences presenting at local and national conferences, put them in a strong position to interview successfully for industry positions. Several outreach activities were also conducted as part of this project including UH Energy Day and Chevron Girls Engineering the Future.

Listed below are the peer-reviewed publications that resulted directly from this award:

Afrin, S., Bollini, P.*, Kinetic Analysis of the Non-Monotonic Response of Ethene Hydrogenation Rates to Ceria Surface Reduction (ChemCatChem) https://doi.org/10.1002/cctc.202400003  

Afrin, S., Bollini, P.*, On the Utility of Ce3+ Spin-Orbit Transitions in the Interpretation of Rate Data in Ceria Catalysis: Theory, Validation, and Application, J. Phys. Chem. C, 127 (2023) 234-247.

Afrin, S., Bollini, P.*, Beyond Upper Bound Estimates of Active Site Densities in Heterogeneous Catalysis: A note on the Critical Role of Titrant Pressure, J. Catal. 413 (2022) 76-80.

Afrin, S., Bollini, P.*, A Transient Kinetic Analysis of the Evolution of a Reducible Metal Oxide Towards Catalyzing Non-Oxidative Alkanol Dehydrogenation, J. Catal. 393 (2020) 290-302.

Afrin, S., Bollini, P.*, Cerium oxide catalyzes the selective vapor phase hydrodeoxygenation of anisole to benzene at ambient pressures of hydrogen, Ind. Eng. Chem. Res. 58 (2019) 14603-14607.
